Instead of providing the link and letting me click, it would be preferable to not show me the link at all.

I assume this bug is security-related. Providing the link to these bugs could be considered as a leak in a way, especially when presented as a dependency of another bug.

comments.text:
I think this is the scenario we're talking about:

A bug exists which can't be checked in until another security bug is first fixed. For example a new API. A user shows up, lets call him Tom, and he is all excited they see that the bug is R+, and A+ed. So Tom says...

Tom: Hey why isn't this committed?

Product owner:  Because it has a blocker, we can't commit it till the blocker is fixed.

Tom: What blocker? i don't see a blocker on the bug!

#Fail...

So showing users that there is a blocker that they can't read isn't a huge deal (this has happened to me a few times), but we might want to do something to let users know that the reason why they don't see a link is because they don't have permissions to view the bug. But I thought we did that already...
